awd_titl_txt: Multi-modal Haptic Stimulations Using Micromachined Ultrasound Processors
awd_abstract_narration:
Emerging wearable electronics having a variety of functions are desirable in seamless human-machine interface applications, including sensors to detect environmental signals and actuators to generate mechanical sensations. Today, numerous sensing systems have been developed for human-machine interfaces to sense signals such as physiological parameters relevant to human health conditions, including electro-cardio signal, pulse wave, blood pressure, and body motion. On the other hand, the progress of wearable mechanical stimulators remains very challenging. For example, traditional actuating systems have used large linear resonators, eccentric rotating masses, and voice coils to generate mechanical stimulations. As a result, these systems are bulky and often stationary with very limited applications. There are several “wearable” prototype stimulators in various research stages such as tactile devices on the fingertips to recreate interaction forces for virtual reality applications, but these systems are still bulky. Several soft and thin actuators have been reported to address the size issue based on piezoelectric polymers to make flexible, thin, and light-weight actuators. However, they require very high driving voltage (hundreds of volts) and they don’t have good spatial resolution for multi-modal stimulations to mimic complex sensations. The proposed project provides unique opportunities by using the acoustic pressure of piezoelectric micromachined ultrasonic transducers (PMUTs) to build small-form factor, wearable, touchless haptic feedback systems via the micromachining process for low-cost manufacturing. The synergy of research and education interaction and integration between manufacturing, material sciences and physical transduction principles will be an engine for the multidisciplinary fusion in research and education expertise for the next-generation scientists and engineers.

The desirable features of wearable haptic devices include: (1) low driving voltage and high output force and/or deformation; (2) thin and small form-factor constructions; and (3) multi-modal stimulations with high spatial and temporal resolutions. This project proposes three innovative approaches to address these challenges: (1) a piezoelectric micromachined ultrasonic transducers (PMUTs) array to generate high ultrasonic radiation force for touchless stimulations irrelevant of skin surface profiles; (2) high temporal and spatial resolutions by a single PMUT chip with multiple actuator units; and (3) varying modals of haptic tactile sensations by amplitude and frequency modulations on individual actuators. As such, this micromachined ultrasound processor could enable exceptional functions and usages in a variety of current and future systems, including cell phones, augmented reality (AR), virtual reality (VR), robotics, … etc., by providing alternative/additional haptic stimulations that are not possible from the current haptic feedback devices.

por.por_cntn:
This project investigates multi-modal haptic stimulations using micromachined piezoelectric ultrasonic transducers (PMUTs). It has addressed key fundamental issues such as design, material, acoustic pressure for radiation force, spatial/temporal resolutions, and multi-modal haptic sensations via modeling, analysis, simulations, optimizations, experiments, and demos for human-machined interface applications. Specifically, current state-of-art wearable haptic devices have several important challenges to achieve: (1) low driving voltage to generate high output pressure/force; (2) thin and small form-factor constructions; and (3) multi-modal stimulations with high spatial/temporal resolutions. As an example, current haptic devices driven by motors have low spatiotemporal resolutions and can only stimulate one kind of responses such as the normal-directional indentation. In this work, we have demonstrated several unique approaches to address these challenges: (1) a PMUTs array to generate high ultrasonic radiation force for touchless stimulations; (2) high temporal and spatial resolutions by an array of PMUTs; and (3) multi-modal haptic sensations. Our results have advanced the PMUT prototype design, material and frequency modulation to achieve several key demonstrations: (1) enhanced output pressure and radiation force more than 10х by advanced structural design; (2) an array of 15x15 PMUTs to generate to 2900 Pa under 12 V (an RMS sound pressure level around 160.3 dB); and (3) successful demonstration of multi-modal touchless stimulations such as force and temperature on volunteers. 

Broader Impacts:  In the area of wearable haptic stimulations, researchers have been working on various prototypes driven by motors (bulky) and thin-film actuators (high voltage/low deformation) for many years without good spatial/temporal resolutions and without the capability of multi-modal stimulations. It would be desirable to explore other schemes such as the micromachined ultrasonic transducers with high spatial/temporal resolutions for multi-modal haptic stimulations. We believe more developments in this area will enable innovative and superior operations of haptic systems with new design concepts and capabilities for applications in AR, VR, robotics and others. To broaden participation of underrepresented group, we plan to offer summer projects via SUPERB (Summer Undergraduate Program in Engineering Research at Berkeley).  It targets first-generation college students, educationally disadvantaged students, or students from historical minority institutions and offers outstanding underrepresented students the opportunity to gain research experiences. In order to stimulate interest in science and engineering, we will provide educational opportunities to high school students in the form of internships. Moreover, we intend to use the research experiences developed in this project as part of the teaching materials in undergraduate course, “Mechatronics Design”, and graduate level course, “Micro/Nano Mechanical Systems Laboratory” to advance discovery and understanding while promoting teaching, training and learning.  In the area of “enhance infrastructure for research and education,” the Berkeley Sensor and Actuator Center (BSAC), of which PI is a co-director, has been a great place to identify and establish collaborations, with more than 20 members from MEMS and nanotechnology industries. We anticipate presenting research results to industrial members and in conferences to disseminate them to broader audience. For the academic world, this research will provide advanced scientific understandings on: (a) high acoustic pressure micromachined ultrasound processor design and material, (b) modeling and simulation of the PMUT array structures and their applications to haptics, and (c) engineering optimization and design processes targeting the haptic devices for human-machine interfaces. For the MEMS/Nano and ultrasonic transducers industry, this proposed project could open a new ultrasonic stimulation (not sensing) business based on the array structures for various potential new business opportunities. For haptics industry and the broad society, results of the proposed research could open a new filed of multi-modal ultrasonic stimulations with the array structure for haptics in AR, VR and robotics applications by advancing the current technologies
